title: Asia stocks take heart in stimulus speculation
text: Asian shares found some footing on Friday after a turbulent week as China hinted at more support for its economy, amid growing expectations of aggressive stimulus from all the major central banks.

title: Bridgewater founder Ray Dalio says there's a 40% chance of a US recession before the 2020 election
text: "Recessions are always inevitable, the only question is: 'When?'," says Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates.

title: Oil gains after strong US retail sales help ease recession worries
text: Crude oil prices rose on Friday after two days of declines, buoyed following data showing a rise in U.S. retail sales helped ease some concerns about a recession in the world's biggest economy.

title: Asia stocks nurse losses, bonds hold huge gains
text: Asian shares were heading for weekly losses on Friday as conflicting messages on the Sino-U.S. trade war only added to worries for the global economy, while talk of aggressive central bank stimulus drove bond yields to fresh lows.

title: Economic Trouble Signs Hang Over Trumpâ€™s Trade War
text: White House advisers discount warnings of a possible recession. But the president may be gambling that the Federal Reserve can ward off that prospect.

title: 'Crazy inverted yield curve' vexes Fed, with no clear resolution
text: Amid the recent financial market volatility, the interest rates on some long-dated government bonds have fallen below the level for short-term debt.

title: Emerging Markets Will Rebound on Trade Deal, Robeco's Fedeli Says
text: Fabiana Fedeli, Robeco's global head of fundamental equities, discusses the impact of global trade tensions on emerging markets with Bloomberg's Romaine Bostick, Joe Weisenthal and Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Markets: What'd You Miss?

title: As investor confidence crumbles, the Fed can act to stave off a recession: Cramer
text: "If bond yields keep plummeting, it might not matter. We'll scare ourselves right out of this terrific multi-year expansion, for certain," Jim Cramer says.

title: Strategist talks inverted yield curve and what investors need to be concerned about
text: J.P. Morgan's Asset Management's Jack Manley discusses the effects of fiscal stimulus fading, trade tensions, business uncertainty which may be leading to an economic slowdown.

title: Cramer: Expect more volatility until the bond market finds some stability
text: "As long as Treasury yields keep plummeting, investors will remain unsure of themselves," Jim Cramer says.

title: Consumers may have to cover cost of tariffs: Trump on trade and more
text: President Trump stops to talk to the media at the airport in Morristown, New Jersey before taking off for a campaign event in New Hampshire. With CNBC's Tyler Mathisen and the Fast Money traders, Pete Najarian, Karen Finerman, Dan Nathan and Guy Adami.

title: We may actually be further away from a China trade deal: FM Trader
text: Discussing President Trump's comments on trade as he prepares to take off for a campaign event in New Hampshire. With CNBC's Tyler Mathisen and the Fast Money traders, Pete Najarian, Karen Finerman, Dan Nathan and Guy Adami.

title: How to navigate all the market volatility
text: Another wild day for stocks. Navigating all the market volatility. With CNBC's Tyler Mathisen and the Fast Money traders, Pete Najarian, Karen Finerman, Dan Nathan and Guy Adami.

title: Renaissance Macro Research's Degraaf: Why small caps continue to fall
text: Jeff Degraaf, chairman at Renaissance Macro Research, joins CNBC's "Closing Bell" to discuss small caps and why they continue to fall behind broader markets.

title: If looking for yield in the market, look toward energy equities: TD Ameritrade's Cruz
text: Shawn Cruz, TD Ameritrade manager, joins CNBC's "Closing Bell" for trade the close to discuss markets and global headlines.

title: Stocks waver, dollar recovers on renewed growth worries
text: The dollar recovered from early weakness but a gauge of world equity performance edged lower on Thursday as concerns about global growth offset investor optimism over a surge in U.S. retail sales last month and strong Walmart earnings.

title: What Investors Should Know About The Yield Curve And Tariffs
text: After a massive selloff and more headlines surrounding the US China trade war, what should investors do now? Michael Reynolds Reynolds, Investment Strategy Officer at Glendmede joins Katherine Ross in studio.

title: Stock Market Today: GE, Cisco and Canopy Make Wild Moves
text: Is General Electric a fraud? Did Cisco, Alibaba and Canopy Growth move big on earnings?

title: Dow Jones Today: When Listless Is a Good Thing
text: Stocks struggled for direction today, but Walmart and Cisco were big movers.

title: Technical strategist walks through emerging and developed global markets
text: Katie Stockton, founder and managing partner at Fairlead Strategies, joins CNBC's "Closing Bell" team to compare emerging markets and developed global markets.

title: US Large-Cap Indexes Close With Gains Thursday
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 25,579.39 on Thursday with a gain of 99.97 points or 0.39%.

title: Stocks end choppy session mostly higher after Wednesday rout
text: Stocks ended a see-saw session mostly higher as investors balanced U.S.-China trade tensions and recession fears with upbeat data on retail sales and solid earnings from Dow component Walmart Inc.

title: Not convinced there are big recession risks on horizon: David Zervos
text: CNBC's "Closing Bell" team breaks down how markets are trading with David Zervos, chief market strategist at Jefferies, and Stephanie Link of Nuveen.

title: Wall Street struggles for direction as bond yields slide
text: Wall Street seesawed from red to black and back on Thursday as recessionary fears and simmering U.S.-China trade tensions offset upbeat retail sales data.

title: Why strategist says the yield curve a broken barometer for recession
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team discusses recession fears that are impacting the markets with David Kelly of J.P. Morgan and John Stoltzfus of Oppenheimer.

title: Recession calls is like saying the sun is going to come up tomorrow: BMO Capital Markets CIO
text: Brian Belski, BMO Capital Markets CIO, joins 'Fast Money Halftime Report' to discuss the calls that a recession will hit the U.S. economy in the next year.

title: What's next for trade talks as global recession fears grow
text: Greg Ip, WSJ, and John Harwood, CNBC editor-at-large, join 'The Exchange' to discuss other steps the U.S. can take in the U.S.-China trade war.

title: Dow falls to Thursday low and 10-year bond slides below 1.5% as ECB official points to shock-and-awe stimulus
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average  fell to its Thursday low in afternoon trade as the market digested reports about coming monetary-policy action out of Europe.

title: You should watch China's non-tariff trade tools, says strategist
text: Meghan Shue, Wilmington Trust senior investment strategist, and CNBC's Steve Liesman join 'Fast Money Halftime Report' to discuss the markets as it comes off of Wednesday's lows.

title: Mixed Signs From The Economy As Sales Climb, Industrial Output Declines
text: The economy offered some mixed signals as retail sales rose for the fifth straight month in July.

title: Recession Risks: Markets Are Right to Price In Higher Probability of Recession
text: Tiffany Wilding, Pacific Investment Management Co. U.S. economist, discusses retail sales, bond yields and the probability of a recession with Bloomberg's David Westin on "Balance of Power."

title: Fed Will Cut Rates in September and Again at the End of the Year, Pimco's Wilding Says
text: Tiffany Wilding, Pacific Investment Management Co. U.S. economist, discusses the outlook for Federal Reserve monetary policy with Bloomberg's David Westin on "Balance of Power."

title: Inside WeWork, one couple wields control
text: In the early days of WeWork, the two people most associated with the company were cofounders Adam Neumann and Miguel McKelvey. As they grew the brand, the pair was interviewed and photographed, together and separately, by numerous publications.

title: WeWork To Go Public: Unprofitable IPO Trend Continues
text: WeWork pioneered space-as-a-service and is the largest player in this new wave of commercial real estate.

title: Wall Street strategists tell clients the yield curve inversion doesn't necessarily mean a recession
text: Wall Street strategists say the yield curve inversion doesn't mean a sign of a recession is coming.

title: Why an Inverted Yield Curve Is Bullish For Stocks
text: An inverted yield curve historically predicts a recession, but stocks tend to rise after an inversion.

title: Bitcoin Stabilizes Near $10,000 After Falling 20% In A Week
text: Bitcoin has been experiencing relative stability today. How long will it last?

title: 'Volatility is here to stay...investors need to be a little bit more cautious," says  Ghabour
text: Key Advisors Group Co-Founder Eddie Ghabour discusses how investors can ride out a volatile market.

title: 2% U.S.Â 30-YearÂ Yield an 'Outrageous Number': Battle
text: In "Futures In Focus," Brian Battle of Performance Trust Capital Partners discusses the outlook for U.S. Treasuries with Bloomberg's Guy Johnson on "Bloomberg Markets."

title: UBS: Gold To Reach Almost $1,700 Next Year
text: "Investors are turning to gold amid expectations of slower US and China growth, dovish central bank policy particularly at the Fed, further declines in real rates, weaker equities and growing concerns of a recession," a recent report states.

title: Investors need to 'take a breath' amid volatility, says CIO
text: Jim Lowell, Adviser Investments CIO, and Deepak Puri, Deutsche Bank Wealth Management CIO, join "Squawk Alley" to discuss the markets after the worst day of 2019.

title: Airlines, automakers hit hard by sell-off and political unrest
text: CNBC's Phil LeBeau takes a look at how Boeing's stock has fared amid the sell-off and its plans to release a new plane, as well as how auto stocks have been hit by recent market volatility.

title: U.S. Retail Sales Top Estimates Behind Surge in Online Sales
text: U.S. retail sales climbed 0.7%in July after a downwardly revised 0.3% increase in the prior month. Bloomberg Intelligence's Seema Shah and JPMorgan Asset Management Investment Specialist Phil Camporeale break down the numbers on "Bloomberg Daybreak: Americas."

title: Mohamed El-Erian: Inverted yield curve recession signal is 'distorted' this time around
text: "If you live in an interconnected world, you have no choice but to import the effect of negative policy rates in Europe," the Allianz chief economic advisor explains.

title: Stock market seesaws as recession fears mix with upbeat data
text: Stocks rose in choppy trading on Thursday but then fell back again as investors tried to balance strong July retail sales data and Walmartâ€™s upbeat results with continuing concerns about the economy slipping into recession. Before 10 a.m.

title: Why Morgan Stanley Raised Its Fed Cut Call to 75 Bps
text: Matthew Hornbach, global head of interest rate strategy at Morgan Stanley, explains his firm's call on Federal Reserve rate cuts and their target for 10-year Treasury yields.

title: China threatens retaliation for US tariffs planned for September
text: CNBC's Eunice Yoon reports from Beijing as China threatens countermeasures against proposed tariffs from the U.S., which are set to go into effect Sept. 1.

title: WH officials: Only Trump, Navarro believe Fed to blame for market volatility
text: CNBC's Kayla Tausche reports on new comments from senior White House officials in which they say the market volatility is caused by trade policy, not Fed policy.

title: China's Government Threatens Retaliation Against US, Trump Calls For 'Personal Meeting' With Xi
text: The U.S.-China trade war escalated further Thursday after China's government stated it will take all "necessary counter-measures" in reaction to the new round of tariffs announced by U.S. President Donald Trump's administration.

title: Jim Cramer on Recession Fears: 'Dial Back the Hysteria'
text: Jim Cramer shares his latest take on the market, and no, he still doesn't see a recession...yet.
